question.text: The resistance of the meter bridge AB in given figure is $4 \Omega$. With a cell of emf $\varepsilon=0.5 \mathrm{~V}$ and rheostat resistance $\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{h}}=2 \Omega$ the null point is obtained at some point J. When the cell is replaced by another one of emf $\varepsilon=\varepsilon_{2}$ the same null point $\mathrm{J}$ is found for $\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{h}}=6 \Omega$. The $\operatorname{emf} \varepsilon_{2}$ is:

solution.text:
Given, Emf of cell, $\varepsilon=0.5 \mathrm{v}$ Rheostat resistance, $\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{h}}=2 \Omega$ Potential gradient is

$\frac{d v}{d L}=\left(\frac{6}{2+4}\right) \times \frac{4}{L}$

Let null point be at $\ell \mathrm{cm}$ when cell of $\mathrm{emf} \varepsilon=0.5 \mathrm{v}$ is used.

thus $\varepsilon_{1}=0.5 \mathrm{~V}=\left(\frac{6}{2+4}\right) \times \frac{4}{\mathrm{~L}} \times \ell$...(i)

For resistance $\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{h}}=6 \Omega$ new potential gradient is $\left(\frac{6}{4+6}\right) \times \frac{4}{L}$ and at null point

$\left(\frac{6}{4+6}\right)\left(\frac{4}{\mathrm{~L}}\right) \times \ell=\varepsilon_{2}$...(ii)

Dividing equation (i) by (ii) we get

$\frac{0.5}{\varepsilon_{2}}=\frac{10}{6}$ thus $\varepsilon_{2}=0.3 \mathrm{v}$
